Expectation1: Look out for each other's safety and well-being
Situation1: One sibling is preparing to try a new skateboard trick on a steep, uneven ramp.
Expectation2: Advocate for policy changes by contacting legislators and participating in lobbying efforts.
Situation2: A key legislative aide has just called and has ten minutes to talk right now about the bill you are campaigning for.
Story: My phone buzzes in my pocket just as I see my younger brother, Max, dragging his skateboard to the top of the old, cracked ramp in our neighborhood park. He’s grinning, helmet askew, determined to land a trick he’s been practicing for weeks. I know how risky that ramp is—last month, someone broke their arm there. I’m supposed to watch out for him, make sure he’s safe, especially when Mom’s not around. But then I glance at my phone: a call from the legislative aide I’ve been trying to reach for months. This is my shot to push for the bill that could change everything for our community. The aide says she only has ten minutes. My heart pounds. Max is already setting up for his run, and I can see the nerves in his eyes. I want to be there for him, to shout encouragement or stop him if it looks too dangerous. But if I miss this call, I might lose my chance to make a real difference. I stand frozen, torn between the ramp and the ringing phone, feeling the weight of both worlds pressing in on me.
